summary: evolution in gradually changing environments has been modeled as a process of adaptation to a moving optimum [17,18,19,20] the lower the rate of change, the smaller the drop in fitness the population experiences in each of the environments to which it is exposed. rapid environmental changes usually produce strong fitness drops that severely decrease the population size and thus the associated genetic diversity. phenotypes obtained under rapid environmental change were fitter [31,32,35] or contained a greater diversity of mutations than those evolving at a slower pace [13,12]. phenotypes obtained under rapid environmental change were fitter [31,32,35] or contained a greater diversity of mutations than those evolving at a slower pace [13,12]. a temperature increase of fixed magnitude but variable rate influenced evolutionary outcomes in an RNA bacteriophage. we used as a model the bacteriophage Q, which infects Escherichia coli strains expressing the F pilus that acts as the virus receptor. the optimal temperature for replication of this virus is 37 °C (the host temperature) the temperature for Q replication was increased from 37 °C to 43 °C either suddenly or following two patterns of gradual change. a variant that could replicate at 43 °C was needed to analyze the adaptive process of Q as a function of the rate of temperature change. 2.1. Evolution of Bacteriophage Q under Different patterns of temperature increase Populations Q-t2 and Q-t25 were the origin for further evolution at an increased temperature following three patterns of change. the sudden pattern (S) entailed an abrupt exposure to 43 °C, after which the temperature was kept constant. the sudden pattern (S) consisted of 60 transfers carried out at 43 °C. in the two-step pattern (TS), the virus was propagated for 30 transfers at 40 °C followed by 30 additional transfers at 43 °C. the gradual pattern (G) involved an increase of 1 °C every 10 transfers. results obtained with the lineages evolved at a higher-than-optimal temperature showed that virus propagation at temperatures above 38 °C always produced fitness increases at 43 °C. fitness increased much faster in populations suddenly exposed to 43 °C, particularly in lineages S-t25, where most of the increase took place during the first 10 transfers.
